entry.title: Auckland SAP Inside Track Event
entry.content:
WHAT: Auckland SAP Inside Track Event

WHEN: 4pm, 25th September 2025

WHERE: Accenture Auckland, Level 5, 131 Queen Street, Auckland

AGENDA:

TOPIC 1: SAP Alphabet Soup - What do I do with BTP, BDC, FRE and AI? 

Glenn Roberts - SAP

With a wealth of experience and a deep understanding of SAP and how customers leverage their important digital assets, come and hear from an SAP Champion as to what to do with your platform investment -  and why it is relevant to organisations that operate in the cloud.

Mika Jun, Okan Soenmez & Johannes Kling - SAP

entry.title: Re: No data entry profile could be determined for CATS
entry.content:
Hello @Bidhu49 

If you are not utilising CATS/HCM, the recommended approach within S/4HANA Public Cloud is to model services as service materials (type DIEN) with standard pricing and to confirm them directly in the Service Order, without integrating timesheets.

Scope/Configuration: Use service confirmation without time recording. See SAP Help for details on service confirmation without time recording.

Pricing: Maintain prices using the Fiori app, Manage Prices ‚Äì Sales (F3890), not VK11/12/13. Check SAP Help: Manage Prices ‚Äì Sales

CATS scope: If you don‚Äôt intend to use time recording, ensure the CATS scope items are not activated. Ref: CATS Integration in Service Management-SAP Learning

This setup allows you to confirm and bill services as sold items (DIEN) without relying on HR or CATS.

Best regards,
Chuma

entry.title: Synchronization between asset master and equipment - Creation of Workflow
entry.content:
Hi all, 
 
I hope someone can help me. After a lot of testing, I am not able to get this running...
 
I am trying to set-up the synchronization between asset master data and equipment. We want to do the sync for changing (not creating) the master data. Everything works fine when we choose "2 direct synchronization"after saving", but I am struggeling with variant "1 Saving triggers a workflow". Accounting want to use the workflow instead of the direct sync, because they want to check e.g. cost center changes first before the asset master data are overwritten. That means, we want to implement a workflow, ifsomeone changes the cost center in the equipment, that an agent has to approve this change first, before the asset master data will be changed. 
 
I tried to follow the steps mentioned in Note 370884, but not all steps are described here and therefore I am pretty sure that I am missing something. Have someone implemented the Workflows WS3100072/-73 or WS3100100/-101 and can help me with the necessary steps? 
 
First question is already the settings in SWEC?
I created the following: 
 
Change Doc.Object: ANLA / Object Category: BO / Business Obj.Type BUS1022 / Event EQUITOBECHANGED
Change Doc.Object: EQUI / Object Category: BO / Business Obj.Type EQUI / Event ASSETTOBECHANGED
 
In SWE2 the Workflows are linked and activated. 
 
In OAWF I linked an agent (US) to the tasks (TS03100055  or TS03100039). 
 
Additionally, I made the setting for Equipment Workflow --> Activate Asset Accounting (Link Object Type with Asset Class) and also I activated the workflow event for our equipment category in the PM Area. 
 
Nevertheless, what I am doing, I do not get the workflow working, only direct sync - even if direct sync is not chosen in customizing.
 
I guess we need to copy the sample workflows mentioned above from SAP, because here no E-Mail or approval steps are involved, correct? Also this I tried already, without any success. 
 
So long story short: I hope someone can help me in that matter, because I do not have any idea anymore what to do/change... 
 
Thanks a lot & Best Regards,
Nina

entry.content:
Hello,

I've received the concern below from a customer and I'm looking for some guidance/workaround to help addressing this issue:

"In the automatic calculation of the amount to be depreciated, SAP only considers open entries that follow a specific schema:

  • Group ID  = G/L Account + Business Partner + Assignment Reference

This means that if the "Assignment Reference" field is not filled in for credit notes or unallocated payments on a customer account, the entry is not taken into consideration in the total amount to be depreciated."

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #3 in the Series
entry.content:
Welcome back to my blog series on the value of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In the first two blogs, I discussed how features such as multi-model engines, infrastructure independence, and a next-generation application foundation all can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

In fact, we‚Äôve already seen powerful confirmation of the value of this database. For example, global consulting services provider CONTAX Inc. migrated to SAP HANA Cloud to gain the elasticity and scalability it needed to handle huge demands on its database resources. This modernization helped CONTAX expand its database capacity while reducing its overall memory footprint and cost by 25%.

That‚Äôs impressive. So how can you best estimate the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud for your enterprise?

Many organizations want to migrate their database to the cloud because they want to build and deploy intelligent applications at scale. But that requires an advanced data landscape architecture‚Äîa database-as-a-service (DBaaS) for modernizing your applications. Let‚Äôs talk about two capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud that help you meet that need and deliver exceptional value: intelligent data tiering and multi-dimensional elastic scalability.

Intelligent data tiering

The exploding growth of business data is both a cost issue and a management challenge for your business. How can you store the data users need and make it easily accessible without busting the budget?

Traditional database technology requires that you choose between database performance and costs. Should you pay more to over-provision storage space so data can be easily persisted in case of growing demands? Or should you archive data to save money but make data harder to access?

With SAP HANA Cloud, you can strike the right balance for your business.

 Intelligent, multi-temperature data management features help you store data in tiers according to type, operational usefulness, access frequency, and scalability requirements. The database locates frequently accessed, business-critical ‚Äúhot‚Äù data in high-performance, in-memory storage, which facilitates real-time processing. ‚ÄúWarm‚Äù data requiring moderate access uses disk storage. Infrequently accessed ‚Äúcold‚Äù data can be stored in a lower-cost data lake optimized for long-term retention and compliance.

By combining tiered storage with advanced virtualization capabilities, SAP HANA Cloud reduces cost and complexity while enabling optimum overall performance. Applications and users can query data at any tier without needing to know where the data is stored. Automatic optimization based on data location and access patterns eliminates complex, costly ETL processes‚Äîwhile supporting both operational efficiency and analytical depth. Data tiering also simplifies application development by offering one interface to multiple data tiers. Developers can use that interface to query data for applications without needing to know where the data is stored.

A recent IDC study [1] assessed database performance impacts for organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Query speed and response time improved by 31% and 29%, respectively. Backups executed 27% faster. Both data load time and recovery time were 24% faster.

‚ÄúData is more accessible with SAP HANA Cloud,‚Äù said one study participant. ‚ÄúIt is also available in real time and loads far quicker than our previous environment. Our data performance has enhanced.‚Äù

Multi-dimensional elastic scalability

Another way SAP HANA Cloud helps you balance performance and cost is by enabling elastic scalability for data processing and storage across multiple dimensions. In today‚Äôs dynamic database environments, short-term processing peaks caused by issues such as period-end reporting surges, seasonal transactions, or heavy analytics workloads can create havoc.

Elastic scalability lets you adjust compute and storage resources based on workload demands, in real time. The database ramps up resources during periods of high demand and then reduces them during low-usage times to conserve costs. Flexible resources include:

  • Performance classes, with flexible CPUs and memory ratios
  • Elastic compute nodes, on-demand resources provisioned in minutes for data-intensive OLAP workloads
  • Dynamic scalability, with individual storage tiers that allow the database to grow or shrink as needed

SAP HANA Cloud also includes elasticity features such as class-based dynamic workload routing, which automatically sends queries to the most appropriate compute resources. An ECN advisor analyzes historical workload patterns and creates optimal provisioning schedules. To prevent scaling events from disrupting application performance, SAP HANA Cloud offers built-in monitoring and workload routing capabilities.

These elastic scalability features help you respond rapidly to changing business needs, enabling optimal performance without over provisioning resources. These features make data more accessible to users while reducing infrastructure complexity. Together, they can help you drive operational agility and cost-effective resource management.

With these benefits in mind, IDC evaluated the infrastructure costs of surveyed companies that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Using its business value methodology, IDC concluded that the infrastructure costs of an SAP HANA Cloud environment were 20% less than a comparable database environment over a three-year period.

According to one study participant operating in the retail industry, ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud has given my organization the ability to scale and reduce redundancy, which are significant benefits.‚Äù

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the next blog to learn how native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines database administrator duties can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

Additional resources:

What‚Äôs the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 

Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.

Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

 [1] ‚ÄúThe Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,‚Äù IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: 5 Things You Need to Know About SAP Datasphere (and where to start)
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs data-driven world, the businesses that thrive are the ones that unify their data and turn raw information into intelligent action. But when it comes to SAP Datasphere, getting started, without losing business context, isn't always clear. 

Whether you're a data analyst, IT expert, or just SAP-curious, this post answers your most common questions about SAP Datasphere, and shows you exactly where to begin your learning journey (especially if you're exploring a career in tech consulting). 

--> Read through üëá. Free resources in the end!

1. What is SAP Datasphere for?  

SAP Datasphere is a unified data service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) that connects, integrates, and models data from both SAP and non-SAP sources, enabling real-time insights for the company. 

Key Capabilities 

  • Data Integration: Connects to SAP and non-SAP cloud/on-premises sources, including data lakes, supports federation, replication, or transformation, and reuses/migrates models from SAP Business Warehouse and SAP SQL Data Warehouse. 
  • Data Modeling: Includes low-code/no-code graphical tools, SQL/data flow editors for modeling, transformation, and replication, with data enrichment from external sources like Data Marketplace, CSV uploads, and third-party systems. 
  • Business Modeling: Provides self-service, multi-dimensional modeling with analytical capabilities and built-in data previews for business users. 
  • Space Management: Enables secure, centralized creation and provisioning of modeling spaces for departments/use cases, with storage allocation, user management, and monitoring tools. 

Business Benefits 

  • Integrates SAP and non-SAP data for real-time, confident decision-making. 
  • Opens the door to advanced analytics, machine learning, and intelligent applications. 
  • Accelerates decision-making with in-memory processing powered by SAP HANA Cloud  

In short, SAP Datasphere unlocks data across applications, data marts, and lakes, while preserving the business context of SAP systems. Powered by SAP HANA Cloud, it enables real-time, in-memory analytics for faster, smarter decisions.  

2. What is the difference between SAP Datasphere and HANA? 

Although both are part of SAP‚Äôs data ecosystem, SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA serve different purposes in data management. 

  • SAP Datasphere is a data management solution built on top of HANA Cloud. Think of it as a fully equipped car, with GPS, dashboard, and controls. 
  • SAP HANA is an in-memory database platform; the engine of the car. 

Key Differences  

 

SAP Datasphere 

SAP S/4HANA  

Scope  & Purpose 

  • End-to-end data management: Integration, governance, quality management, analytics, and security 
  • Primarily a high-performance database platform that supports applications and data storage 

Architecture & Deployment 

  • Cloud-native service on SAP HANA Cloud, built for multi-cloud and multi-source data 
  • Can be deployed both on-premise and in the cloud 

Modeling Capabilities 

  • Graphical, low/no-code tools for both business and technical modeling, with built-in previews 
  • Technical views with advanced flexibility (e.g., multiple outputs, post-aggregation calculations) 

Data Integration 

  • Real-time and batch data from SAP and non-SAP sources, including data  lakes 
  • Typically relies on more traditional data extraction methods 

User Experience 

  • Designed for business users: less technical, easier to model and manage 
  • Offers more technical control but requires greater technical expertise 

Analytics & Consumption 

  • Native integration with SAP Analytics Cloud + open APIs for BI tools 
  • Serves as a data platform that can support multiple analytics solutions 

 

3. Is SAP Datasphere replacing BW? 

Not exactly, but it's the future-focused evolution of SAP‚Äôs data warehousing capabilities. 

SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA are still supported and will be until at least 2040. However, SAP Datasphere represents a modern, cloud-first approach that gives organizations greater flexibility, integration power, and future-readiness 

Transition Paths for BW/BW/4HANA Customers 

  1. Fully migrate to SAP Datasphere and decommission SAP BW or BW/4HANA 
  2. Retain BW or BW/4HANA but extend with SAP Datasphere capabilities for a hybrid solution.  
  3. Lift BW or BW/4HANA into SAP Business Data Cloud landscape to use as a data source.  

Migration Options 

  • SAP BW Bridge: A component within SAP Datasphere that offers SAP BW capabilities directly in the public cloud, including connectivity and business content for SAP BW-based data integration.  
  • Conversion tools: Both shell conversion and remote conversion options are available for migrating from SAP BW 7.x and SAP BW/4HANA to SAP BW Bridge.  

Hybrid Use Case  

In hybrid scenarios, you can expose BW/4HANA models directly in Datasphere, so business users can reuse existing logic without rebuilding from scratch. Then, you can enrich those models with new data and semantics from external sources. 

4. Is SAP Datasphere an ETL? 

No. SAP Datasphere is not exclusively an ETL tool, but rather a full data management platform that goes beyond Extracting, Transforming, and Loading processes. It helps you integrate, govern, model, and analyze your data across both SAP and non-SAP systems, all while preserving business context. 

ETL Capabilities Within Datasphere 

  • Data Flows: Enable batch-driven ETL processes with built-in transformations like filtering, joining, projecting, and even simple Python scripting. 
  • Transformation Flows: Support complex transformations with calculated fields, unions, aggregations, and delta handling for optimized performance. 
  • Replication Flows: Provide real-time data replication with change data capture (CDC) support from external sources. 
  • Data Integration & Orchestration: Federate or replicate data across SAP and non-SAP sources, including data lakes, cloud apps, and on-premises systems.

Tools for all skill levels 

Use graphical low-code/no-code tools or powerful SQL/data flow editors for: data preparation, real-time or batch integration, and advanced transformation scripting support both real-time and batch data integration from various sources 

Beyond SAP Datasphere‚Äôs ETL Functionality  

ETL is just one layer. SAP Datasphere also includes: 

  • Data governance 
  • Semantic modeling 
  • Business logic preservation 
  • Secure, scalable space management 
  • Built-in integration with analytics tools like SAP Analytics Cloud  

5. How does SAP Datasphere fit into SAP Business Data Cloud? 

SAP Datasphere is the core data layer of SAP Business Data Cloud. It connects the dots between raw data (from SAP and non-SAP sources) and the analytics layer that drives business insights and intelligent applications. 

Core Position in the Architecture 

Data products provide individual data sets from SAP applications but lack essential business semantics needed for direct consumption by analytics tools. Therefore, SAP Datasphere addresses this gap by providing the necessary semantic enrichment and modeling capabilities. 

Essential Component Status 

While it‚Äôs technically possible to form a Business Data Cloud setup without SAP Datasphere, doing so limits your ability to: 

  • Integrate data from SAP, customer, and partner sources 
  • Build unified models across different systems 
  • Enable intelligent applications that rely on business semantics 

Key Functions within SAP Business Data Cloud 

  • Data Access & Enrichment: Replicate or virtualize data products and enrich them with filters, formulas, and custom logic.  
  • Semantic Enhancement: Define dimensions, hierarchies, units, dates, and aggregation types of measures.   
  • Custom Modeling: Create reusable models combining SAP, customer, and partner-managed datasets.  
  • Application Enablement: Power intelligent applications through secure, SAP-managed modeling spaces.  

üîµReady to Get Started with SAP Datasphere? 

Whether you're just learning the ecosystem or aiming to step into tech consulting, SAP‚Äôs free training program is the best place to begin.  

üëâVisit Digital Skills Center for more information.  

Availability of our programs may vary by country; check for open calls and program details specific to your region. 

For more details, check out these resources 

  • What is SAP Datasphere and what benefits does it bring to your business? 
  • Getting Started with SAP Datasphere 
  • Demystifying SAP Datasphere - SAP Community 
  • SAP Datasphere 
  • Get Started with SAP Datasphere
  • Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud 

Special thanks to @adeyemi_depiver for collaborating in this article.

entry.title: PPF action with action profile LMD_OUTPUT fails (LMD Integration in S/4 HANA)
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We are currently facing an issue with LMD integration in S/4 HANA. When executing a PPF action with the action profile LMD_OUTPUT, the PPF actions fails even though the configuration was carried out according to the SAP documentation.

One of our developers already debugged the process in transaction SPPFP (action: LMD_POST_ROUTE_PROC_TRACKING). According to the analysis, the processing fails because the system cannot find any SLD (System Landscape Directory) access data. At the relevant code point, an exception is triggered.

Since we did not notice any inconsistencies in the customizing settings, I would like to ask the SAP Community:

  • Which settings regarding SLD/LMD connections need to be maintained for the PPF action to work?
  • Is it necessary to configure system connections or RFC destinations on SAP Basis level (e.g. to SLD or other components)?
  • Is there a way to configure the LMD implementation to work without external system calls?

Has anyone faced a similar issue implementing the LMD integration in S/4HANA and can share insights?

Thanks a lot in advance :-)!

Kind regards,

Nicole Heinz

entry.title: Re: There is no valid rule step for SKDV
entry.content:
Hello @Wayne10 

The error ‚ÄúThere is no valid rule step for SKDV‚Äù indicates that the valuation rule is having trouble locating a semantic-tag mapping within the Financial Statement Version (FSV) associated with your accounting principle.

  • Within the Starter system, FSV 1099 (DE) is supplied with the necessary semantic tag assignments.
  • Within your Customising system, if you're using FPA1 instead, you'll need to replicate the semantic tag mappings from 1099 into FPA1 under the CBC/SSCUI activity 'Assign Semantic Tags to Financial Statement Versions'. Without this mapping, the SKDV rule won‚Äôt have a valid step to execute.

The solution is to copy the semantic tag setup that was delivered from 1099 to FPA1. If you need 1099 to be available in your system, you can also request the delivered content to be activated.

Check below documentations

  • 3602288 - Error "There is no valid rule step for SKDV" when running Advanced Foreign Currency Valuation - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • CBC Activity 105450 ‚Äì Assign Financial Statement Versions to Accounting Principles
  • Managing Financial Statement Versions-SAP Learning
  • SAP Help ‚Äì Configuring Advanced Foreign Currency Valuation

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to Prevent MRP from Covering Shortages Before the...
entry.content:
SAP MRP setup to plan only against future PIRs

I hear the frustration: you want MRP to stay disciplined and order only for your forward-looking PIR plan, not chase past gaps caused by overselling. The cleanest way to get there is to stop past/near-term consumption from eating into future PIRs, and to constrain MRP‚Äôs planning window so proposals reflect only the horizon you actually intend to replenish.

Core levers to align MRP with your PIR horizon

1) Tighten or disable PIR consumption across periods

  • What to do: In Customizing (Demand Management), set the consumption mode and backward/forward consumption periods at MRP Group level so sales orders cannot consume PIRs outside a very tight window‚Äîor at all. Setting the periods to 0 prevents cross-period consumption; forward-only with a small window can also work if you still want very near-term smoothing.
  • Why it helps: Overselling today won‚Äôt reduce the PIRs for next month, so MRP won‚Äôt ‚Äúsee‚Äù a reduced PIR and try to backfill earlier gaps with new PRs. SAP explicitly notes that PIR consumption behavior is determined in customizing; configuring this is the decisive control point.

2) Constrain the planning horizon to your forward window

  • What to do: Maintain the planning horizon (days) in OPPQ/OPPR and/or at plant/MRP Group level to match your PIR horizon. Use horizon planning (which you already have) together with a strict planning horizon so the net requirements calculation and proposal creation occur only within that window.
  • Why it helps: Even if there are shortages ‚Äútoday,‚Äù the system won‚Äôt generate proposals outside your defined window, keeping PRs aligned to the future PIR bucket plan instead of firefighting past due gaps.

3) Treat past shortages as informational, not actionable

  • What to do: Use shortage profiles/definitions in the MRP apps to monitor uncovered demand without forcing procurement signals. Configure the scope and priority of shortage calculations for visibility while letting your purchasing strategy ignore them operationally.
  • Why it helps: You still see risks, but PR creation stays governed by the PIR horizon and your planning rules.

Optional reinforcements if you still see ‚Äúgap-filling‚Äù PRs

  • Firming and time-fence behavior: Keep the planning time fence but ensure your firming type prevents creation or rescheduling inside the fence; the horizon itself should be where proposals get created and aligned to PIR buckets. If firming is strict but you still see PRs, the culprit is usually consumption, not firming.
  • Lot sizing aligned to PIR buckets: Use fixed lot sizes or period lot-sizing (e.g., weekly/monthly) that match your PIR cadence. This nudges MRP to propose neatly per PIR bucket rather than fragmented gap coverage.
  • Rescheduling vs. new creation: Tune rescheduling horizon and exception messages so the system suggests reschedule-in instead of creating fresh PRs for near-term gaps you intentionally won‚Äôt cover.
  • Availability date logic: Ensure requirement dates are not brought forward by lead-time settings or aggressive scheduling margins that unintentionally pull proposals into the near term.

When standard config isn‚Äôt enough: targeted enhancements

If the above controls don‚Äôt fully decouple early shortages from future PIR-driven proposals, consider these BAdIs to hard-enforce your policy:

  • Flexible PIR consumption: A BAdI that governs which demands can consume PIRs (e.g., block past/near-term sales orders from reducing future PIRs).
  • Change MRP data during the run: A BAdI that can suppress proposal creation for demands outside your horizon or reclassify certain near-term shortages as non-plannable.
  • Add/modify MRP elements: As a last resort, adjust which elements MRP ‚Äúsees‚Äù for netting when they fall before the planning start.

These are commonly used to codify business-specific guardrails when configuration alone can‚Äôt express the rule set cleanly.

Practical implementation checklist

  1. Set consumption mode and periods at MRP Group:
    • Goal: zero or minimal cross-period consumption so early sales do not reduce future PIRs.
  2. Align planning horizon (OPPQ/OPPR) with your PIR horizon:
    • Goal: PR creation only in the intended forward window.
  3. Review firming type and time fence:
    • Goal: block creation/rescheduling inside the fence that contradicts your replenishment policy.
  4. Adopt bucketed lot sizing aligned with PIR cadence:
    • Goal: one clean PR per PIR bucket, not gap-fillers.
  5. Use shortage definitions for visibility only:
    • Goal: monitor uncovered demand without triggering PRs.
  6. If needed, activate a BAdI to lock down consumption rules or suppress non-horizon proposals:
    • Goal: enforce ‚Äúplan to the future PIRs only‚Äù under all conditions.

Why this works

  • PIRs are designed to represent planned demand independent of sales and can be protected from cross-period consumption via customizing. Doing so prevents overselling today from cannibalizing tomorrow‚Äôs plan and stops MRP from chasing those past gaps.
  • Planning horizon settings ensure MRP calculates and proposes supply only within your forward window, rather than attempting to resolve earlier imbalances that you have intentionally chosen not to cover.
  • Shortage profiles let you keep operational awareness without altering procurement behavior, so your purchasing stays aligned to strategy rather than exceptions.

If you can share a sample material‚Äôs settings (MRP Group, consumption mode and periods, lot size, firming type, planning horizon days, lead time), I can suggest exact field values and where to change them.

entry.title: Re: SAC - Measure Column Script in onActive Function
entry.content:
Hi,

The function setDimensionFilter() works only on dimensions, not on measures. When you create a measure column in the story, such as counting a dimension, it exists only in the SAC front-end layer and is not part of the HANA query. Because of this, you cannot directly filter a table on that calculated measure through scripting. Instead, you can push the logic to HANA by creating the calculated measure in the HANA view and then filter it using a variable or you can use ranking or thresholds directly in the SAC table without scripting.

entry.title: Re: How to Prevent MRP from Covering Shortages Before the...
entry.content:
MRP still covering early shortages: how to force ‚Äúplan only to future PIRs‚Äù

You‚Äôve done the right things conceptually (time fence + forward-only consumption), but two typical culprits still let early sales erode future PIRs: residual PIR consumption/reduction settings and proposal creation/rescheduling allowed inside or up to the fence. Here‚Äôs how to lock it down so MRP proposals align only with the PIR horizon.

Key fixes to try

1) Eliminate cross-period PIR reduction entirely

  • Set consumption to none at the MRP Group.

    • Consumption mode: 0 (No consumption), and keep backward/forward = 0/0.

    • Assign the MRP Group to the materials so they inherit this rule.

  • Turn off PIR reduction by sales altogether.

    • In the requirement class/strategy used for PIRs, switch off ‚ÄúReduce requirements‚Äù so sales orders cannot reduce PIRs.

    • If you don‚Äôt need sales to consume PIRs at all, choose a strategy group that does not consume PIRs, or override via MRP Group.

  • Why: Your current forward window (60 days) still allows earlier sales to nibble at future PIRs that fall inside that 60-day lookahead. ‚ÄúNo consumption + no reduction‚Äù is the clean break.

2) Enforce a hard planning window for proposal creation

  • Planning time fence (PTF): Keep 79 days, but pair it with a firming type that disallows new order proposals and rescheduling inside the PTF.

    • Use a firming type that:

      • Does not create new proposals inside the PTF, and

      • Does not reschedule-in existing proposals into the PTF.

  • Planning horizon (days): Maintain at plant/MRP Group level so the system only creates proposals for dates within your intended future window (beyond ‚Äúnow,‚Äù not before it).

  • Why: Even if there‚Äôs a ‚Äúshortage‚Äù today, MRP won‚Äôt be allowed to propose anything before your horizon.

3) Align lot sizing to PIR buckets

  • Lot size: Use period lot sizing (weekly/monthly) that matches your PIR cadence or a fixed lot size per bucket.

  • Why: MRP then creates one clean PR per bucketed PIR, instead of multiple ‚Äúgap-filling‚Äù PRs.

4) Tame rescheduling and exceptions

  • Rescheduling horizon: Set to 0 (or minimal) so you don‚Äôt get reschedule-in proposals that pull supply into the near term.

  • Exception messages: Disable or down-prioritize ‚Äúreschedule-in‚Äù inside the PTF to avoid operational pressure to cover the past.

 

Master data checks on a sample material

  • MRP Group assigned: Confirms the material inherits ‚Äúno consumption, no reduction‚Äù and PTF behavior.

  • Strategy group / requirements type for PIRs: Use a variant where PIRs are not reduced by sales orders; if unsure, enforce at MRP Group level.

  • Consumption fields blank at material level: So MRP Group settings dominate (no accidental overrides).

  • Scheduling margins / safety time: Ensure these don‚Äôt pull dates forward into the fence.

  • Availability check / scope: Avoid settings that advance requirement dates or create hidden near-term coverage pressure.

 

If standard config still isn‚Äôt enough

  • Consider a small enhancement to enforce your policy:

    • Flexible PIR consumption: Enhancement to block any sales-order consumption of PIRs outside the exact PIR bucket window (or entirely).

    • Change MRP data during the run: Suppress proposal creation for demands dated before the horizon or reclassify them as non-plannable.

  • These are lightweight and commonly used when business policy requires ‚Äúfuture-only‚Äù planning regardless of historical gaps.

 

Quick diagnostic to pinpoint the leak

  1. Run MRP with:

    • Consumption mode = 0, back/fwd = 0/0 at MRP Group.

    • Firming type that forbids creation/rescheduling inside the 79-day PTF.

    • Rescheduling horizon = 0.

  2. Check:

    • Do PIR quantities remain intact despite past overselling? If yes, consumption/reduction was the issue.

    • Do any PRs appear inside the PTF? If yes, firming/rescheduling settings need tightening.

    • Are PRs dated neatly to PIR buckets? If not, adjust lot sizing to period-based buckets.

entry.title: Moderation on SAP Community
entry.content:
SAP Community moderators ensure that the content on our site and that our members comply with our rules of engagement, as well as with other policies and guidelines (such as the Digital Services Act). They review content submitted to the site (particularly content from new members) and respond to reports about rules violations. They also monitor the site for potential violations. 

Upon discovering violations, moderators may remove content, alter content (to bring it into compliance), ban members (either temporarily or permanently, depending on the severity of the violation), or issue warnings. Where necessary, they‚Äôll ensure that all actions follow the Digital Services Act (DSA). Whenever possible, they‚Äôll coach members to help them understand and follow our rules, as their primary goal is to create a positive environment where members can contribute and grow. 

The moderation team follows several processes -- based on the type of content submitted or the nature of a violation. 

Pre-Moderation for New Members 

 Questions, answers, discussions, and comments from newer members (not employed by SAP) pass through pre-moderation. This pre-moderation ensures that this content complies with our rules of engagement and reduces the likelihood of spam and other inappropriate content appearing on SAP Community. (To learn about moderation for blog posts and knowledge-base documents, please see the next section.) 

When newer members submit questions, answers, discussions, and comments for SAP Community, their content will enter a pre-moderation queue, where it will be reviewed to ensure compliance with our rules. They will also receive a message informing them that their content requires pre-moderation. 

Upon submission new members will be notified that the post is in moderation, and will be released if it is approved: 

You can find your queue of unmoderated posts, and their status here. If the content is appropriate, it will be published. If it isn‚Äôt, it won‚Äôt. Spam will be removed from the queue before reaching the site, and anyone caught attempting to publish spam will be banned.  

 Pre-moderation takes up to two hours, Monday through Friday. New members who submit content over the weekend will need to wait until Monday before pre-moderation takes place. 

To bypass pre-moderation, newer members will need to demonstrate that they understand our guidelines and are willing to comply with our rules. Over time, once they‚Äôve shown that they wish to contribute positively to SAP Community ‚Äì by submitting content that consistently passes through pre-moderation successfully ‚Äì they‚Äôll gain the ability to post directly to the site. We won‚Äôt share any details beyond that, as we don‚Äôt want to give spammers information that will help them work around pre-moderation. Also, we don‚Äôt reveal details about gamification, the rank ladder, and privileges because per our FAQs, we want to ‚Äúkeep members focused on general quality participation.‚Äù  

Note that the pre-moderation process doesn‚Äôt apply to established members who have been contributing regularly to SAP Community. It also doesn‚Äôt apply to knowledge-base documents and blog posts ‚Äì just to other types of content (e.g., questions, answers, discussions, comments/replies in threads). The process for blogging and document moderation remains unchanged. 

 

Blog and Document Moderation 

To blog, members (whether employed by SAP or not) must first complete our SAP Community tutorial, ensuring that they take all of the actions outlined in the tutorial. 

Curators or owners review all blog posts submitted to their groups. They decide whether the content is appropriate for a group‚Äôs audience. They conduct these reviews, and make their decisions, independently of the SAP Community moderation team. 

Elsewhere in SAP Community, our moderation team reviews submissions from new bloggers for the various ‚Äúby members‚Äù and ‚Äúby SAP‚Äù blog boards. After review, a moderator either approves the post or sends it back to the author with feedback. Blog reviews from our moderation team can take up to five business days for each submission. In other words, if a moderator sends a post back to an author with feedback, and the author makes the necessary changes and submits the post again, it may take up to another five business days before the second review occurs. This process occurs each time the author submits a post for review, so if a member wishes to go through moderation more quickly, he or she should take the time to ensure that the post complies with standards and guidelines, as outlined in the tutorial and the rules of engagement.  

To notify our moderators that your post is ready for them, please make sure that you click the ‚ÄúSubmit for Review‚Äù button in the blogging tool. Save as a draft if you‚Äôre still working on the post. Please don‚Äôt submit a post for review if you plan to keep working on it. Also, please only submit one post at a time for review. Once the moderation team works with you and approves a post, you may work on another and submit it for review.    

To check on the status of your submission, navigate to the Blog Dashboard for the blog board where you submitted your post for review and click ‚ÄúView All Drafts.‚Äù  



After clicking "View All Drafts," you'll see the status, version number, and other information for your submission:‚ÄØ 

By clicking on the submission's title, you can check the history of the submission to see whether a group owner, curator, or moderator provided feedback -- explaining that the post has been rejected or outlining what steps are necessary to qualify for publication.‚ÄØ 

You just need to click "View History," as seen above, to get these details:‚ÄØ 

To bypass blog moderation, members need to move up the rank ladder, although groups curators and owners must always approve blog posts for their groups, regardless of the author‚Äôs rank. Members can climb the ranks through consistent, positive activity and contributions. You can learn more about the various SAP Community ranks (and how to climb the rank ladder) in this post. 

To publish a knowledge-base document in a group, members require the approval of a curator or owner for that group. Curators or owners review documents submitted for their knowledge-base boards, determining whether the content is a good fit, just as they review submissions for their blog boards. 

Note that this moderation process doesn‚Äôt apply to questions, answers, discussions, comments, and other content from newer members. This process only applies to the moderation of blog posts and documents. To learn more about the pre-moderation process that applies to questions, answers, replies in threads, etc., please refer to the previous section above. 

 

Moderation of Content/Members Reported as Inappropriate 

Members can report other members and their content for violations. When they do so, our moderation team will review the report and determine what steps are required (if any). 

You‚Äôll find the option for reporting inappropriate content from the dropdown menu next to posts, answers, comments, etc., throughout the site. Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll see when reporting a question, for example:

Selecting this option will bring you to a series of menus, as well as a text field, allowing you to provide details about why you‚Äôve reported the content. 

When reporting content, it‚Äôs important to indicate whether the content violates the Digital Services Act (DSA), as DSA violations require additional actions from our moderation team (versus reports for common moderation activities, such as fixing tags).

In most cases, you‚Äôll simply choose ‚ÄúNon-DSA related alert to moderators‚Äù for the reason ‚Äì as this selection applies to the majority of reports that our moderation team receives (for requests to move content to another area, remove/correct a tag, and so on). 

If you pick ‚ÄúNon-DSA related alert to moderators‚Äù as the reason, the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu will remain grayed out. (Since the reason is unrelated to a DSA violation, no additional selection is required.) You‚Äôll still have the option to enter additional information (in the ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù field). For example, you can point out an incorrect tag (and propose a better one) before submitting the report by clicking the ‚ÄúNotify Moderator‚Äù button. 

This information helps our moderators understand the nature of the issue and work with members quickly to fix the problem, minus the formality of DSA steps that require stiffly worded messages and legally sounding explanations. For non-DSA cases, the moderators can work with members in a capacity that doesn‚Äôt feel overly official, creating a much friendlier experience for the members involved.  

In situations where something does violate the DSA, our moderation team follows the procedures outlined by this act, including messaging the member reported as well as the member who submitted the report ‚Äì making sure they are aware of the nature of the violation, what steps have been/will be taken, how they can protest a decision, and so on. Given the complexity associated with the management of DSA violations, we ask that you make certain that it‚Äôs a true DSA offense before reporting it as such. 

When alerting the moderation team about a DSA violation, you‚Äôll need to select one of the reasons beneath the dashed line (underneath ‚ÄúNon-DSA related alert to moderators‚Äù), such as ‚ÄúIllegal Or Harmful Speech‚Äù and ‚ÄúUnsafe And/Or Illegal Products.‚Äù 

This action opens the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu, where you‚Äôll need to select the item related to the reason. There are several to choose. 

Since we have mapped these reasons and specifications to DSA systems (which is where we need to upload data about our DSA-related activities), we must make sure that we open and submit every DSA case accurately. You can help by selecting the right reason (distinguishing between non-DSA and DSA alerts) and DSA specification (in the event of actual DSA violations) carefully when reporting content that requires moderation. 

Not sure which selection to make? You‚Äôll see some helpful suggestions right next to the menus, providing guidance about what to select and why for common scenarios. 

As an example, if you want to report spam, select ‚ÄúViolation of Terms of Use‚Äù for the reason and ‚ÄúOther‚Äù from the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu. (Remember to add some information in the details to help our moderators understand why you‚Äôre reporting the content.) 

In addition to reporting content, you can report members. In fact, if a member has published multiple pieces of content that violate our rules, we recommend that you report the member instead of his or her individual posts. That way, our moderation team only needs to process one report (for the member) versus multiple reports (for all of the content). You can report members by clicking on their name anywhere in SAP Community (such as in a byline for a blog post), finding ‚ÄúOptions‚Äù on their content page, and clicking ‚ÄúReport User.‚Äù 

One last piece of important advice: Negative feedback and curt comments aren‚Äôt against the law, and they don‚Äôt qualify as harassment and hate speech under DSA regulations. To be more specific, as an example, DSA defines hate speech as ‚Äúillegal incitement to violence and hatred based on protected characteristics.‚Äù Therefore, before reporting member comments as misconduct under DSA, consider whether they can be categorized as illegal speech. Per our‚ÄØBasic Etiquette and Tips for Participating in SAP Community‚ÄØguidelines, members should keep discourse civil and try to work out differences, reporting member comments only when they are truly harmful and in violation of DSA regulations. Disagreements and criticism are not grounds for moderator action ‚Äì especially under DSA. 

 

Contacting the Moderation Team 

You can learn more about our moderation team on our Points of Contact page. If you have specific questions about moderation actions, please contact‚ÄØmoderators@sap.com.

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors Customer Conversations with Cadent Gas
entry.content:
We are excited to invite you to our upcoming LIVE event featuring Cadent Gas, the UK's largest gas distribution network. Join us to hear firsthand about Cadent Gas‚Äôs successful HR transformation and how they achieved significant enhancements in employee experience and operational efficiency with SAP SuccessFactors solutions.

Register here!

About Cadent Gas: 
Cadent Gas brings gas to 11 million homes and businesses. With over 6000 employees, the company manages a network of more than 82,000 miles of pipes, most of them underground, which transport gas throughout the Northwest, West Midlands, East Midlands, South Yorkshire, East of England and North London.

Agenda: 

  • Company overview
  • Insights into Cadent Gas‚Äôs HR strategy and the challenges faced
  • Implementation journey using a phased approach
  • Best practices and lessons for success
  • What‚Äôs next: Talent Intelligence Hub, Opportunity Marketplace and AI tools
  • Interactive Q&A session


Challenges and Highlights:
Cadent Gas's HR transformation journey included the phased implementation of SAP SuccessFactors. Starting with the establishment of a dedicated HRIS team and centralizing HR activities, they leveraged SuccessFactors to enhance manager capabilities and streamline HR processes. In the next phase, Cadent Gas implemented Employee Central as the self-service core HR master system, as well as optimizing the recruiting, onboarding, and learning experiences. Cadent Gas is now building on this foundation, by implementing the Talent Intelligence Hub and Opportunity Marketplace, as well as integrating AI tools to accelerate efficiency within their HR operations.

SAP Solutions:

entry.title: ROLE AUTHORIZATION PFCG
entry.content:
Good afternoon,

Let's see if someone can help me with this role issue because it's not easy at all.

I've been working with SAP for a while but I can't seem to find the solution. Let me explain:

1) I have a user (USER1) with several assigned roles. This user does not have authorization to access Tx SE16.

2) I have a role created by me (ROL1) that allows access to SE16 and contains the following: - Authorization object S_TCODE - TCD SE16 - Authorization object S_TABU_NAM - ACTVT 03, TABLE ZXX1.

3) I have another empty user (USER2). If I assign the role created by me (ROL1), it works perfectly, and the user has access to SE16 for table ZXX1. If, for example, I try to access table ZXX2, it doesn't let me because there is no authorization. So far, everything is fine.

Now comes the strange part:

4) If I assign my role (ROL1) to user USER1, who has several roles assigned but does not have access to SE16, the user can access SE16 (correct because ROL1 allows it), but in addition to being able to access ZXX1, they can also access ZXX2 and all tables in the system.

Why can they access all tables if they only have access to ZXX1?

How can I configure it so that USER1 can only access certain tables?

Thank you in advance for your help.

entry.title: Re: Object type definition for an outbound IDoc
entry.content:
This topic is quite old by now, but if anyone stumbles across this issue like I just did, there seems to be a note now that provides a solution. (Haven't tested it yet myself)

See 2427697 - Missing outcomming IDOC (DESADV) in ASN (advanced shipping notification) - SAP for Me

As already mentioned beforehand the entry in TBD14 is the problem. By deleting the entry for DESADV, the system is supposed to determine the object type dynamically from the business application.

Cheers!

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud add-in for Microsoft Office
entry.content:
Hello,

You will not see the SAP Analytics Cloud add-in automatically. It has to be installed from the Office Add-ins Store by going to Insert ‚Üí Get Add-ins ‚Üí search for ‚ÄúSAP Analytics Cloud.‚Äù If it is not available there, it usually means that your IT has disabled access to the Office Add-ins Store, and in that case the IT administrator needs to deploy it centrally through the Microsoft 365 Admin Center.

From my experience, however, the SAP Analytics Cloud add-in is not as useful as the SAP Analysis for Excel add-in, because the SAC add-in does not support Live BW models and works only with imported models or Datasphere models. For this reason, I personally prefer using the SAP Analysis for Excel add-in.

entry.title: Re: ROLE AUTHORIZATION PFCG
entry.content: Use transaction SUIM > Users by complex criteria and ask if USER1 has S_TABU_NAM - ACTVT *, TABLE ZXX2. Let SUIM search the roles for you.

entry.title: Re: Value Mapping usage in XSLT Mappings with CPI
entry.content:
Hi Robert, 

just wanted to point out that your groovy script might return wrong values due to race conditions. This may lead to weird behaviour and could be hard to debug.
The reason are undeclared variables in the script, essentialy making them shareable across iFlow instances. You should declare all variables, at least with 'def'.
See SAP Note 3457571 for details, could save you from trouble in high load scenarios.

Best regards,
Thomas

entry.title: SAP AI Training und SAP AI Skills Self-Assessment
entry.content:
Es steht au√üer Frage: Der Aufbau von KI‚ÄëKompetenzen ist heute entscheidend. Weil es so viele M√∂glichkeiten gibt, haben wir f√ºr Dich wichtige SAP KI Lernangebote kuratiert. Hier im Blog findest du:

  • Ein kurzes SAP AI Skills-Assessment - zur eigenen Einsch√§tzung als erster Schritt
  • Kostenfreie Lernangebote nach Job-Rolle f√ºr KI-Beginner, Berater, Entwickler
  • Lernangebote zu Embedded AI in SAP L√∂sungen 
  • Trainer-gef√ºhrte Schulungen, in denen KI eine zentrale Rolle spielt 
  • KI Lernangebote mit SAP Learning Hub Abo ‚Äì wie Live Sessions und √úbungssysteme 
  • Zertifizierung(en)

Komme gerne zur√ºck auf diese Seite, denn da KI so dynamisch ist und so viel passiert, werden wir die Seite mindestens einmal pro Monat updaten.  

Training nach Job-Rolle

hier gibt es u.a. folgende digitale kostenlose Lernangebote in englischer Sprache, weitere sind auf der √úberblicksseite zu finden.  

GrundlagenBusiness User  AdministratorBerater

Joule Agents verstehen und nutzen: Entscheidungsfindung verbessern und KI-Funktionen integrieren.

SAP Business AI entdecken | 40 Min 

Wie SAP Business AI Gesch√§ftswert schafft durch Prozessautomatisierung, bessere Entscheidungen und Innovation.


KI-Ethik bei SAP | 1 h

SAPs KI-Ethikprinzipien, Governance-Framework und Regeln f√ºr verantwortungsvolle KI-Entwicklung und -Einsatz.

SAP Business AI f√ºr Finanzen entdecken | 3,5 h
SAPs KI-gest√ºtzte Finanzl√∂sungen incl., wie SAP Business AI Finanzprozesse durch datengetriebene Erkenntnisse und optimierte Abl√§ufe transformiert.


Hochwertige Einsatzm√∂glichkeiten f√ºr Agentic AI identifizieren | 2 h
Beherrsche den Joule Agent Discovery Workshop, um wertvolle KI-Agent-Anwendungsf√§lle f√ºr dein Unternehmen zu identifizieren und zu priorisieren.

Menschenzentrierter Ansatz zur Identifikation von Business AI Use Cases
| 1 h 45 min
Lerne, wie du AI-Use-Case-Workshops durchf√ºhrst und nimm an unserer Spot-the-Difference-Challenge teil, um Workshop-Materialien zu gewinnen.

SAP Business Technology Platform erkunden | 4 h
Einf√ºhrung in die SAP Business Technology Platform und die Intelligent Enterprise Strategie.


SAP Process Orchestration kennenlernen | 4 h

Einf√ºhrung in SAP Process Orchestration und die Advanced Adapter Engine Extended (AEX).


Bereitstellung und Admin von Datenbanken in SAP HANA Cloud | 8 h 
Bereitstellungs- und Administrationsaufgaben in SAP HANA Cloud durchf√ºhren.

 

 

 

 

 

Provisioning and Implementing Joule I 2h

Konfiguration und Integration von Joule, SAPs KI-Copilot, √ºber verschiedene SAP-Plattformen hinweg zur Produktivit√§tssteigerung und technischen Optimierung.

 

 

Fortgeschrittene KI-Techniken mit SAPs Generative AI Hub | 1 h 39  
Aufbauend auf KI-Grundlagen: Fortgeschrittene Techniken wie Data Masking, Content Filtering und Vector Embeddings im SAP Generative AI Hub anwenden.

 

 

 

 

 

Technische SAP KI Lernangebote 

F√ºr Entwickler und technische Rollen empfehlen wir folgende Lernangebote

  • Provisioning and Implementing Joule - 2h
  • Using Advanced AI Techniques with SAP‚Äôs Generative AI Hub - 1h 39
  • Navigating Large Language Models fundamentals and techniques for your use case - 2h 47
  • Solving Your Business Problems Using Prompts and LLMs in SAP's Generative AI Hub - 5h 35  
  • Learning how to use the SAP AI Core service on SAP Business Technology Platform - 2h 42

Lernangebote zu Embedded AI 

SAP bietet derzeit 295 AI Features und Agenten (aktuell im AI Katalog) - anbei eine Auswahl an Lernangeboten dazu

  • Introducing SAP Business AI for SAP Spend Management Solutions
  • Introducing SAP Business AI for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Introducing SAP Business AI for SAP SuccessFactors HCM
  • Discovering SAP Business AI Capabilities for SAP Finance
  •  Introducing SAP Business AI for SAP Supply Chain Management

SAP Schulungen - trainergef√ºhrt 

Trainergef√ºhrte Schulungen von SAP bieten ein Lernerlebnis das virtuell oder in SAP Schulungszentren stattfindet mit realen Anwendungsf√§llen, Zugang zu √úbungssystemen und SAP Experten. In folgenden Schulungen spielt KI eine zentrale Rolle. Nach Auswahl des Landes findest Du konkrete Termine zum Buchen. 

 

  • SAP Business Technology Platform - Erhalte eine Einf√ºhrung in die SAP Business Technology Platform.

  • Introduction to SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Administration
    Lerne SAP BTP-Administrations-Grundlagen kennen, einschlie√ülich Architektur, Tools, Sicherheitsmanagement und Anwendungslebenszyklus-Management in verschiedenen Laufzeitumgebungen.

  • Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud 
    Einf√ºhrung in SAP Business Data Cloud und die Data Engineering-Komponenten von SAP Business Data Cloud.

  • Explore SAP SuccessFactors Solutions
    √úberblick √ºber Funktionen und Features der SAP SuccessFactors Suite, verf√ºgbar in verschiedenen Lernformaten und Bereitstellungsoptionen.

  • SAP SuccessFactors Performance and Goals Academy 
    15-t√§giger virtueller Kurs zur Konfiguration von SAP SuccessFactors Goal Management und Performance Management, prim√§r konzipiert f√ºr SAP-Partner-Berater mit Zertifizierungs- und Bereitstellungsanforderungen.

  • SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting: Recruiter Experience Academy
    Lerne die SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting-Konfiguration, einschlie√ülich Systemeinrichtung, XML-Anpassung und Gesch√§ftsregeln, konzipiert f√ºr SAP-Partner-Berater mit Zertifizierungsanforderungen.

SAP AI Training im SAP Learning Hub

Mit einem SAP Learning Hub Abo gibt es viele zus√§tzliche "premium" Lernangebote wie Live-Sessions durch Experten, √úbungs-systeme, Zertifizierungs-Gutscheine sowie Zertifizierungs-Updates, Learning Analytics und vieles mehr. Anbei ausgew√§hlte KI Inhalte:

  • Deep Dive into Joule Skills | 45 minutes | 23-SEPT-2025 - Hands-on session with Joule, SAP's AI Copilot, featuring live demos and practical guidance for driving efficiency and productivity in your organization.
  • Extend Joule Skills via Joule Studio in SAP Build | 45 minutes | 16-SEPT-2025 - Hands-on session on extending Joule with custom skills using Joule Studio in SAP Build, featuring live demos of creating and deploying tailored business automations.
  • Exploring the Latest Features of SAP BTP AI Services | 1 hour | 20-NOV-2025 - Learn about recent updates and new capabilities in SAP AI services available on SAP BTP, with a focus on new features and improvements.
  • Implementing Real-World AI Models on SAP BTP | 1.5 hours | 11-NOV-2025 - Learn how to implement AI models on SAP BTP, with a focus on practical business use cases and deployment strategies.
  • Optimizing AI Prompts for Business Tasks in SAP BTP using Generative AI Hub | 1 hour | 30-OCT-2025 - Live session on prompt management and optimization techniques for AI-driven business tasks using SAP Generative AI Hub in SAP BTP.
  •  SAP Business Technology Platform Pillars ‚Äì AI Solutions | 2 hours | 11-NOV-2025 - Introduction to AI solutions in SAP BTP including embedded intelligence, machine learning services, and real-world business use cases.

√úbungssysteme im SAP Learning Hub

Es gibt bereits verschiedene √úbungssysteme, in denen man verschiedene AI Features ausprobieren und damit experimentieren kann. Das sind viele Systeme zu SuccessFactors oder SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) - anbei eine kurze Auswahl.

  • S4C* (Sandbox) Joule activated/7 AI features activated
  • S4C LSC tenants Joule activated/7 AI features activated
  • S4D400/401/430 Joule (J4D: Joule for ABAP Developers) chat function on ADT
  • C4H62 AI scenario: Account Takeover Protection
  • S4TM2 AI scenario: Conversational Planning
  • IBP (all 17 courses for 2508) Joule activated in Practice Systems, but no dedicated exercises

SAP KI Zertifizierungen 

SAP Certified Associate - SAP Generative AI Developer ist derzeit die erste Zertifizierung, weitere folgen die n√§chsten Monate, was wir auch hier updaten. Diese Zertifizierung  best√§tigt, dass du SAPs Business AI-Funktionen verstehst und √ºber die F√§higkeiten verf√ºgst, SAP BTP-Anwendungen zu erweitern, w√§hrend du f√ºhrende Large Language Models (LLMs) nutzt, unter Verwendung von SAP AI Core/SAP AI Launchpad und SAPs Generative AI Hub. 

 

 
Warum SAP AI Training?
  • Original von SAP: Inhalte direkt vom Softwareanbieter ‚Äì aktuell, produktnah, qualit√§tsgepr√ºft.
  • Praxisfokus: Hands-on Lernen, reale Use Cases, Zugang zu "echten" SAP KI Experten
  • F√ºr Profis: Lernpfade f√ºr SAP Berater, Entwickler und Experten ‚Äì vom Einstieg bis Fortgeschritten

H√§ufig gestellte Fragen (FAQ)

Was ist SAP Business AI?

SAP Business AI umfasst KI-Funktionen in SAP-Anwendungen und Plattformdiensten: Joule (KI-Copilot), eingebettete KI-Szenarien, Machine Learning auf SAP BTP und Entwicklungstools wie Joule Studio. Diese Technologien automatisieren Prozesse, liefern Datenerkenntnisse und steigern die Produktivit√§t.

 

F√ºr wen sind SAP AI Trainings geeignet?

  • Business/Key User: F√ºr deine t√§gliche Arbeit mit KI-Tools
  • Administratoren: F√ºr die Implementierung von KI-L√∂sungen
  • Berater: F√ºr die Kundenberatung zu SAP-L√∂sungen
  • Entwickler: F√ºr die Erweiterung von KI-Funktionen
Wir bieten Lernpfade f√ºr alle Kenntnisstufen.

Gibt es Voraussetzungen f√ºr SAP AI Trainings?
  • Einf√ºhrungskurse: Grundkenntnisse von SAP-L√∂sungen
  • Entwickler-Kurse: Vorteilhaft sind Programmierkenntnisse wie Python
  • Fortgeschrittene Kurse: Teilweise Erfahrung mit SAP BTP erforderlich
 

Was kosten SAP AI Trainingsangebote?

  • Kostenlos: Selbstlernkurse, Webinare, Tutorials
  • Einzelkurse: Ab ‚Ç¨840/Tag (Instructor-led)
  • SAP Learning Hub: ‚Ç¨640 (Partner) und ‚Ç¨1.200 (Kunden) j√§hrlich
 

Wie lange dauert der Abschluss von SAP AI Lernpfaden?

  • Einf√ºhrung: 10-15 Stunden
  • Rollenbasiert: 20-40 Stunden plus √úbungen
  • Zertifizierung: 40-80 Stunden inkl. Pr√ºfung
Die Kurse sind f√ºr berufsbegleitendes Lernen konzipiert.
 

Wie hilft mir SAP AI Training bei meiner Karriere?

entry.title: CAP - How to Update Association of Remote Entity without Duplicating Entries in Local DB ?
entry.content:
Dear Reader, 

I have a question about how to deal with remote associations when updating their values from my local CAP application.

Imagine having a schema like this:

entity Products : cuid {
    name  : String;
    price : Integer;
    order : Association to Orders;
    /*
    totalQuantiy : type of order.TotalQuantity;
    startDate    : type of order.MfgOrderPlannedStartDate;
    endDate      : type of order.MfgOrderPlannedEndDate;
    */
}

entity Orders                      as
    projection on API_PRODUCTION_ORDER_2_SRV {
        key ManufacturingOrder,
            TotalQuantity,
            MfgOrderPlannedStartDate,
            MfgOrderPlannedEndDate,
    }

My local CAP application has a Fiori-Eelements frontend and displays all the fields of "Products" in an object page and I dynamically add associated fields to "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" from remote entity "Orders". So when I am reading my "Products" I expand the read to the remote entity with my custom handler, everything is fine. 

But what if I want to update certain elements, like "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" from the remote entity?
My Entity "Products" is draft enabled, but changes in the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" of the association are not triggering any "PUSH" or "UPDATE" event in the backend. 

The problem is, I don't want to persistently add the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" to the entity "Products", that is why I added them in /* */.
I tried making them virtual or computed fields, but then they are also read-only for the Fiori frontend and no event is triggered when changing them. New values are also not delivered to the backend on "save" button in the frontend. 

So the question for me remains, is it only possible to send draft values from the frontend to the backend on persistently saved elements ?
or is there another way I am missing, to somehow allow me to change the values in the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" and receive the new values in the backend, so I can update the remote entity ?

I hope i explained the problem somehow understandable, otherwise feel free to tell me so I can update üôÇ 

thanks for your time, greetings

David

entry.title: Re: Internal error (3998) occurred [Message 131-183] when adding document in SAP B1
entry.content:
Hello Asim,

From what i remember this had to do with the permissions of the (new in version 10) users xx_RW and xx_RO users. Depending on how you restore/update the test DB, you might be overwriting the existing _RW and _RO users with those of the live db. After you do a "refresh database user" in the SLD for the test database, it refreshes these users and their permissions so then you need to double check they have the required one.

I think you need to see in SLD which RW and RO user is assigned to that test DB, then go into the SQL server and see what permissions the corresponding users have on the live databases (which i suppose are working fine) and then apply these on the RW and RO users of the test database.

Hope that helps,

Spyros

entry.title: Re: I am facing issue while debugging SAP MDK code in VS...
entry.content:
It looks like you are using definitions received from App Update.  Please verify that when the metadata was deployed from BAS to Mobile Services you answered Yes to the "Include source map file for debugging?" question.

You can confirm this by looking at the .project.json for the SourceMap option

	"Build": {
		"SourceMap": true,
		"TSTarget": "es6",
		"WMF": true,
		"Platform": "iOS & Android"
	},

If it is false, change it to true and redeploy from BAS.  Then update the definitions on your client from Mobile Services and try again.

entry.title: Re: SAC # Charts # Y Axis Line
entry.content:
Hi,

To show the Y-axis in your SAP Analytics Cloud chart, follow these steps:

  1. Click on the chart to activate it.

  2. Click the three dots (More Actions) in the top-left corner of the chart.

  3. Go to More Options > Show/Hide.

  4. In the submenu, check the option "Y-Axis Labels" (as shown in the image below).

This will enable the Y-axis labels on your chart.
